sentences.sentence: The key determinant of improved living standards is improved labour productivity - essentially, the value of goods and services people produce per hour of work.

As Canada recovers from the pandemic, one of the consequences of larger government may be slower productivity growth and, ultimately, lower living standards.Government borrowing and spending reallocate productive "inputs" (labour, for example) from the private sector to the government sector to facilitate the provision of government services.

If inputs are used more efficiently in the private sector, using them to instead produce more government services will reduce overall productivity growth.The difference(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=3610048001) in productivity growth between the government and private sectors in Canada is dramatic.

Using the standard measure - real output per hour worked - labour productivity increased by 31 per cent in Canada's business industries between 2000 and 2020, compared to just 12 per cent in the government sector.Moreover, government's productivity performance has been deteriorating.
Labour productivity in the government sector increased by only 4.5 per cent between 2010 and 2020, compared to 7.3 per cent in the previous decade.
(By contrast, labour productivity in business industries increased by 8.7 per cent from 2000 to 2010 and by 20.5 per cent from 2010 to 2020.

)Some economists may object to a direct comparison of productivity changes in the private and government sectors, noting that governments provide services while businesses provide both goods and services.

If it's more difficult to improve productivity in service delivery than in the production of goods, government will be at a disadvantage in any direct comparison of productivity performance.Terence Corcoran: Canada's first 'net-zero' carbon fiasco(https://financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-canadas-first-net-zero-carbon-fiasco)Don Drummond: A message from the Ghost of our Fiscal Future(https://financialpost.com/opinion/don-drummond-a-message-from-the-ghost-of-our-fiscal-future)Matthew Lau: The Liberals should be more pro-choice on childcare(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-the-liberals-should-be-more-pro-choice-on-childcare)But consider this: in businesses that only produce services, labour productivity increased by 38 per cent between 2000 and 2020 - more than three times the 12 per cent increase in the government sector noted above.

To be sure, there are problems in measuring service-sector outputs and productivity, especially in the case of government services, where in the absence of market prices the value of output has to be imputed.
It's therefore best to be cautious when comparing productivity performance in the government with private-sector service industries.

Even so, the differences in productivity growth rates are large and persistent.A second possible objection is that some government services (education, for example) facilitate faster productivity growth in the private sector.
Hence, we should credit some portion of measured productivity growth in the private sector to the government sector.

But while it can be argued that a healthier and better-educated workforce facilitates more rapid productivity growth in the private sector, a substantial portion of government activity may actually harm private-sector productivity.

For example, excessive government regulation discourages productivity-enhancing capital investments and innovation, particularly among small and medium-sized(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/ch4-drag-on-productivity-from-excessive-regulation.pdf) firms.

On balance, the overall activities of government may actually discourage(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/changing-size-of-government-in-canada-2007-2018.pdf) rather than promote private-sector productivity growth.As policymakers in Ottawa and across Canada consider the appropriate size and scope of government in the emerging post-pandemic era, it's important to give proper weight to the consequences of larger government for our long-run productivity performance.

The problem is not just that a greater share of our future incomes will be diverted from private spending to pay down government debt, but that those future incomes will be substantially lower than they could have been due to the growing size of government.Steven Globerman is a resident scholar at the Fraser Institute and is co-author of the Institute's new study Industry-Level Private Sector Capital Expenditures in Canada(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/industry-level-private-sector-capital-expenditures-in-canada-1990-2019).
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
documents.inputText: The key determinant of improved living standards is improved labour productivity - essentially, the value of goods and services people produce per hour of work. As Canada recovers from the pandemic, one of the consequences of larger government may be slower productivity growth and, ultimately, lower living standards.Government borrowing and spending reallocate productive "inputs" (labour, for example) from the private sector to the government sector to facilitate the provision of government services. If inputs are used more efficiently in the private sector, using them to instead produce more government services will reduce overall productivity growth.The difference(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=3610048001) in productivity growth between the government and private sectors in Canada is dramatic. Using the standard measure - real output per hour worked - labour productivity increased by 31 per cent in Canada's business industries between 2000 and 2020, compared to just 12 per cent in the government sector.Moreover, government's productivity performance has been deteriorating. Labour productivity in the government sector increased by only 4.5 per cent between 2010 and 2020, compared to 7.3 per cent in the previous decade. (By contrast, labour productivity in business industries increased by 8.7 per cent from 2000 to 2010 and by 20.5 per cent from 2010 to 2020.)Some economists may object to a direct comparison of productivity changes in the private and government sectors, noting that governments provide services while businesses provide both goods and services. If it's more difficult to improve productivity in service delivery than in the production of goods, government will be at a disadvantage in any direct comparison of productivity performance.Terence Corcoran: Canada's first 'net-zero' carbon fiasco(https://financialpost.com/opinion/terence-corcoran-canadas-first-net-zero-carbon-fiasco)Don Drummond: A message from the Ghost of our Fiscal Future(https://financialpost.com/opinion/don-drummond-a-message-from-the-ghost-of-our-fiscal-future)Matthew Lau: The Liberals should be more pro-choice on childcare(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-the-liberals-should-be-more-pro-choice-on-childcare)But consider this: in businesses that only produce services, labour productivity increased by 38 per cent between 2000 and 2020 - more than three times the 12 per cent increase in the government sector noted above. To be sure, there are problems in measuring service-sector outputs and productivity, especially in the case of government services, where in the absence of market prices the value of output has to be imputed. It's therefore best to be cautious when comparing productivity performance in the government with private-sector service industries. Even so, the differences in productivity growth rates are large and persistent.A second possible objection is that some government services (education, for example) facilitate faster productivity growth in the private sector. Hence, we should credit some portion of measured productivity growth in the private sector to the government sector. Fair enough. But while it can be argued that a healthier and better-educated workforce facilitates more rapid productivity growth in the private sector, a substantial portion of government activity may actually harm private-sector productivity. For example, excessive government regulation discourages productivity-enhancing capital investments and innovation, particularly among small and medium-sized(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/ch4-drag-on-productivity-from-excessive-regulation.pdf) firms. On balance, the overall activities of government may actually discourage(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/changing-size-of-government-in-canada-2007-2018.pdf) rather than promote private-sector productivity growth.As policymakers in Ottawa and across Canada consider the appropriate size and scope of government in the emerging post-pandemic era, it's important to give proper weight to the consequences of larger government for our long-run productivity performance. The problem is not just that a greater share of our future incomes will be diverted from private spending to pay down government debt, but that those future incomes will be substantially lower than they could have been due to the growing size of government.Steven Globerman is a resident scholar at the Fraser Institute and is co-author of the Institute's new study Industry-Level Private Sector Capital Expenditures in Canada(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/industry-level-private-sector-capital-expenditures-in-canada-1990-2019). !@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc.
